intro: Brassica oleracea convar. acephala, commonly known as cauliflower, is a cool-season crop characterized by its dense, white inflorescence. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family and is cultivated for its edible flower heads, which are formed by the tightly packed buds. The plant typically grows to a height of 40–100 cm and has thick, fleshy leaves that surround the central head. It requires well-drained soil and moderate temperatures for optimal growth. The genetic diversity within this cultivar contributes to its adaptability and resistance to various diseases.
